column2: 大
矮小之人必定畏惧大块头。\n―― 维克多・雨果
column3: The little people must be sacred to the big ones. - Victor Hugo
column4: The little people must be sacred to the big ones. - Victor Hugo
column6: The little people must be sacred to the big ones. - Victor Hugo

column2: 高
无论你的祖父有多高大，你都必须要自己长大。\n―― 亚伯拉罕・林肯
column3: You have to do your own growing, no matter how tall your grandfather was. - Abraham Lincoln
column4: You have to do your own growing, no matter how tall your grandfather was. - Abraham Lincoln
column6: You have to do your own growing, no matter how tall your grandfather was. - Abraham Lincoln

column2: 矮
我宁愿当个高大的普通人，也不要做个矮小的天才。\n―― 梅尔・布鲁克斯
column3: I'd rather be tall and normal than a short genius. - Mel Brooks
column4: I'd rather be tall and normal than a short genius. - Mel Brooks
column6: I'd rather be tall and normal than a short genius. - Mel Brooks

column2: 小
恰当的广告使许多小东西变得很大。\n―― 马克・吐温
column3: Many a small thing has been made large by the right kind of advertising. - Mark Twain
column4: Many a small thing has been made large by the right kind of advertising. - Mark Twain
column6: Many a small thing has been made large by the right kind of advertising. - Mark Twain

column2: 舒缓的嗓音
此人的声音自然舒缓。它既不有力也不悦耳，但它的柔和能够抚慰愤怒的人们，狡猾地说服多疑的人们。
平静的嗓音
没有语言像爱尔兰语那样舒缓而安静。
column3: There is no language like the Irish for soothing and quieting.
column4: There is no language like the Irish for soothing and quieting.
column6: There is no language like the Irish for soothing and quieting.

column2: 刺耳的嗓音
他们简洁而浮华的歌曲/在他们可怜的秸秆的管子上划拉。\n―― 约翰・弥尔顿
column3: Their lean and flashy songs/Grate on their scrannel pipes of wretched straw. - John Milton
column4: Their lean and flashy songs/Grate on their scrannel pipes of wretched straw. - John Milton
column6: Their lean and flashy songs/Grate on their scrannel pipes of wretched straw. - John Milton

column2: 响亮的嗓音
我从人们的心里摘下了忠诚/他们口中的大声叫喊和招呼\n―― 莎士比亚
column4: I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts/Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths - Shakespeare
column6: I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts/Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths - Shakespeare
column9: I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts/Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths - Shakespeare

column2: 安静的嗓音
凡事只要大声说出来，都会出现些许改变。\n―― 赫尔曼・黑塞
column3: Everything becomes a little different, as soon as it is spoken out loud - Herman Heese
column4: Everything becomes a little different, as soon as it is spoken out loud - Herman Heese
column6: Everything becomes a little different, as soon as it is spoken out loud - Herman Heese

column2: 好听的嗓音
魔鬼的声音是甜美的。\n―― 史蒂芬・金
column3: The devil's voice is sweet to hear. - Steven King
column4: The devil's voice is sweet to hear. - Steven King
column6: The devil's voice is sweet to hear. - Steven King

column2: 粗哑的嗓音
没有什么东西能影响我的声音了，它是如此糟糕。\n―― 鲍勃・迪伦
column3: Nothing can affect my voice, it's so bad. - Bob Dylan
column4: Nothing can affect my voice, it's so bad. - Bob Dylan
column6: Nothing can affect my voice, it's so bad. - Bob Dylan

column2: 快
如履薄冰，唯快不破。\n―― 拉尔夫・沃尔多・爱默生
column3: Skating over thin ice, our safety is in our speed. - Ralph Waldo Emerson
column4: Skating over thin ice, our safety is in our speed. - Ralph Waldo Emerson
column6: Skating over thin ice, our safety is in our speed. - Ralph Waldo Emerson

column2: 机敏
惊喜的诀窍在于守口如瓶和突如其来。\n―― 克劳斯维茨
column3: The backbone of surprise is fusing speed with secrecy. - Clauswitz
column4: The backbone of surprise is fusing speed with secrecy. - Clauswitz
column6: The backbone of surprise is fusing speed with secrecy. - Clauswitz

column2: 僵硬
当我的身体没有青肿，疼痛或僵硬的时候，我不知道那是什么感觉。\n―― 莎拉・米歇尔・盖拉
column3: I have no idea what my body feels like when it's not bruised, sore, or stiff. - Sarah Michelle Gellar
column4: I have no idea what my body feels like when it's not bruised, sore, or stiff. - Sarah Michelle Gellar
column6: I have no idea what my body feels like when it's not bruised, sore, or stiff. - Sarah Michelle Gellar

column2: 笨拙
水从不笨拙。\n―― 马修・麦康纳
